reviewText: Fenix Rage brings back the fun of classic hardcore platformer action. It's mainly inspired by Super Meat Boy and most levels really have the same difficulty as you had in Super Meat Boy. If you are an old-skool gamer like me you will have lots of fun with this challenging game. Instead of raging I'm mostly smiling. Why? Because hardcore platformers almost aren't produced (anymore). Super Meat Boy has been a while back now, and after completing that it was really time for some new hardcore platformer to make me frustrated and give me a real challenge.\n\nThe game has over 200 levels, each as frustrating as any and each level can be played in 3 different modes: normal, challenge and godmode. I am yet to figure out what godmode is, as I haven't unlocked that yet. Normal let's you play through the levels, well.. normally"
date: while challenge gives you even more of a challenge by limiting the dashes and jumps you can make per level. Besides that there's also one cookie in every level to collect to unlock (real-life!) recipes and there's hidden "red cubes" which you can collect to unlock a bonus world with hidden levels that give you even more of a challenge.\n\nThere's 4 different themed worlds
recommended: each with their own unique (challenging and frustrating!) boss and after you beat the last one you unlock another 4 new themed worlds
hoursPlayed: which are inspired on the levels from the first 4 worlds

reviewText:
Fenix Rage is clearly influenced by Super Meat Boy. Different from SMB is the ability to dash, providing the gamer a reward of finishing a level more quickly at the risk of not having as much control over Fenix. The gameplay is flawless. It is truly the gamer's fault for dying -- which you will, a lot -- and not the game getting in the way of itself.

The only negative thing I can say about this game is that my hand became tired while playing the first boss level as I was frantically trying to dash and jump my way through the level. At the time of this review I have played through the entire first world obtaining all the cookies in those first 20 levels.

I would consider this a must play if you enjoy the highly difficult yet satisfying platforming games.

reviewText:
This is more a mixed review than a negative one.

I purchased Fenix Rage because the experience seemed similar to Super Meat Boy, but two factors have depleted my motivation to continue. (I'm currently in the middle of World 5.)

There is a distinct lack of enemy variety. Predominantly, all you'll see are enemies that move back and forth in a straight line, or that jump in place, which is nearly the same thing. It isn't until you've completed around 80 levels that you'll see enemies with different movement patterns, and by that point I had already grown tired of the level design. Even many of those later levels apparently focus on the straight-line enemies.

Similarly, maneuvering Fenix often involves no more than button-mashing to take a straight line through openings in between the aforementioned enemies. In most cases, you'll either mash the jump button to ascend, or the dash button to move sideways. There are no precise wall kicks or nuanced, curved jumps, and Fenix's vertical speed feels rather slow. The idea of infinite jumps and air dashes sounded exciting, but ended up being more simplistic and repetitive than I expected.

If neither point fazes you, and you seek another precision platformer, I'd say there's a good chance you'll enjoy this, even if it didn't quite meet my personal expectations. Otherwise, perhaps you'd be better off with another entry in the genre.

reviewText: This is one of the most fun games I've played in a long time and by far the toughest. I just finished the game and I put in about 9 hours into it. reviewText: Fenix Rage is an excellent purchase for fans of hardcore platformers.  If you like Super Meat Boy, IWBTG, Electronic Super Joy, or VVVVVV then you will no doubt enjoy this game.  The challenge-level is equivalent to SMB, however Fenix Rage presents enough new tricks and challenges to make this a unique game.\n\nAs Fenix, you have an infinite number of air-jumps and air-dashes at your disposal for manuevering past enemies and traps.  The goal of all 200 levels is to simply reach the blue-block at the end.  Clever level design from beginning to end ensures that even seasoned platformer fans can expect a satisfyingly twitchy 9+ hours of gameplay to 100% the game.

reviewText:
Why is there RNG in my precision platformer? And why so much of it especially? Like, I just. I can't get past that. A lot of the bosses and even some of the stages (world 5 especially) have huge RNG factors in their levels. In a precision platformer! Idiots! Ugh.

Oh, also, it's not really a platformer? No need to jump between platforms, you have infinite jump and dash. It's more a flying game than a platformer, and that's fine, the levels are designed with that in mind.
But then. Why are the walls so sticky if you literally have no reason to wall jump, ever? Really quite annoying.

And a good chunk of the levels in the game are just... enemy spam. No rhyme or reason, toss enemies everywhere, just let the player figure it out, WHATEVER AHAHA. That's another thing. There's just too many levels, for how little creativity is on display. It gets stale, the only really big shift comes in world 9, where a lot of the better levels are simply due to being unique, but even that world has some enemy spam levels too.

All the worlds are pretty visually indistinct, as well. Bright colors, thick line style, similar fake-guitar gamey-type music that I turned off at some point out of annoyance. Can't tell the worlds apart. It even does the super meat boy dark world" type thing (not even close to the only thing it steals from that game and doesn't understand; cookies = bandages
recommended: etc.) but because the worlds are so indistinct it doesn't even matter. And the dark world remixes of a lot of levels... aren't noticeably different. Really the game barely even has a difficulty curve

reviewText:
I had a great time so far with Fenix Rage. It has a very Super Meat Boy feel to the controls which is great. But what makes the game really fun is the clever level design.

I appreciate the instant restarts. When a game is a brutal as this one is sometimes then I really want to get back in the action right away. But don't get me wrong, the levels are well crafted making you think about how to approach a series of obstacles either through trail and error or pausing for a moment to mentally traverse the level planning an optimal route.

The first couple levels show the game mechanics in a rather uninspired way. But you won't stay bored for long, the game almost immediately starts challenging your skills and focus. New mechanics are introduced regularly and continue to ramp the difficulty of the game nicely.

The inclusion of extra mini-games is welcome as well. It nice they thought about rewarding players with more than just achievements for completing the games extra challenges. They might be just short distractions, but much better than nothing.

Overall if you like challenging platformers I recommend you pick this one up. I doubt you will be disappointed.

reviewText:
Fenix Rage is a hardcore 2d platformer which could be simply described as 'Super Meat Boy on steroids' :P Really fast paced experience thanks to two things: infinite vertical jump ability and dash. You'd think that it makes levels easier, but nope. You have to have even more extreme reaction time than in SMB :P What else? Sweet, colorful graphics, nice music, REALLY tight and responsive controls, great game overall!

There's only one thing that's a little bit problematic. That is restart of the lever after you die. It's instant plus it doesn't reset enemies patterns. So it doesn't give you that split second to prepare yourself to the next attempt.

But it's just really minor thing that doesn't ruin that really nice game :)

reviewText:
Disclosure - I worked on this game.  Full disclosure - I still love it.

Fenix Rage marries the best things about many other platformers while bending conventional thinking.  My personal favorite is the fact that in most platformers you need...well...platforms.  In Fenix Rage it's optional to land on one in each given level once you take off.  Some levels don't even have platforms.  With infinite jump and infinite dash are given to you you'd think that a platformer should be easy...right?

Well...no.  Fenix Rage is not for the faint of heart.  If you don't like frustratingly difficult levels levels, or sweating on your controller, or shouting curse words then you probably won't enjoy this game.  That's the honest truth.  However, if you do like a challenge, the satisfaction of completely hardcore levels, and most importantly bragging rights with your friends, then you'll REALLY like this one.

With over 200 levels each world offers new challenges that keep you on your toes throughout the entire game.  With these types of games tight controls are extremely important and Fenix Rage doesn't deal the cheap death card.  When you die, it's your fault.  With each death you will learn...if only a little...what you did wrong.

When you work on a game for a long time by the time you launch it the last thing you want to do is play it.  That's not the case with Fenix Rage for me.
voteText: 22 of 40 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I played this game for the first time at PAX and was hooked almost instantly. The controls are incredibly responsive and the levels are almost always innovative.

Fenix is as difficult as you want it to be. Just want to get to the end of each level? That's fine, touch the blue square and you've unlocked the next level. Want to finish it fast? Great, each level has a time to beat, and you get a gold star if you do. Want to finish it efficiently? Challenge mode limits the number of jumps and dashes you get to reach the end, and you'll get a red star. Are you a manifestation of pure, unbridled skill? Play Godmode like the god you are.

Another review I read described it as a Super Meat Boy + Flappy Bird + Sonic the Hedgehog hybrid.. which is pretty accurate. For what it's worth, I'd say it's less grotesque than Super Meat Boy, far less repetitive than Flappy Bird (what isn't), and far more responsive than Sonic.

Perhaps my favorite design feature in this game is that you respawn instantly after dying. I mean INSTANTLY. In Super Meat Boy, there's about 1/3 second of delay after you die, but in Fenix Rage, it's literally a few milliseconds before you can move again. Did you screw up during the stage? Push one button and BOOM instant respawn. It's amazing.

From a pure gameplay perspective, Fenix wins. He just feels... powerful. However, the game could be more polished in its ambiance. The music is okay, but not as memorable as it is in VVVVVV or Dustforce. Dustforce actually creates an amazing ambiance with lush backgrounds, although that might just be my personal aesthetic preference.

Lastly, this is just my personal gripe but none of these platformers ever has a real plot. They're always pretty half-baked, which is to be expected given the focus is on the gameplay, but still it would be nice to have say a choose your own adventure type deal with a good ending / bad ending / different levels depending on what you pick. But chances are good you don't care about that stuff anyway.

8.5/10. Please buy this game so I can expect more great stuff from these devs :)
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An astounding piece of game design and one of the most unsung Indie games of recent years.

It's contemporaries would arguably be games along the lines of Super Meat Boy possibly Dustforce. Run and jump (or dash in this case) from a to b in increasingly difficult levels, split across uniquely defined worlds with boss fights. The real pull of the game as with the above noted titles being that once you've ran from start to finish you'll want to do it again and again and again until you're pulling out your hair / balding and have smashed a controller but have perfected 1 of 200 levels, thus the name Fenix RAGE....it's a game which finds an absolute sweet spot for balance between prompting ragequit and outright leaderboard addiction.

When I did most of my playthrough of this I was jumping between two titles, Super Meat Boy & Fenix Rage. It amazed me just how much Fenix rage could take small influences from a game which is undoubtedly top of the tree but still not feel in anyway inferior or like a blatent rip and the reason for that is because they share similar themes, both can be crushingly difficult if you're going for perfect runs, both encourage leaderboarding but from a pure mechanics point of view this is it's own game. The dash mechanics, the sliding down walls to set your character on fire and melt through ice or becoming ice to drop through a laser unharmed - it's extremely subtle but very, very clever and all packaged up nicely with exceptional character design / artwork and a memorable retro soundtrack.

It's one of those games that most people that played loved enough to drop gushing reviews but when a game has at time of writing 95 reviews clearly not enough people played it.

**as far as im aware the game will relaunch on console as Fenix Furia and a large PC patch will follow in the coming months which im hopeful along with introducing the multiplayer which I've seen being played at Gaming Expos, possibly Steam Cloud saving, possibly fully functional steam overlay, will give this game it's second wind and a degree of the success on Steam which such a well made and fun game deserves**
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I wrote a review that you can find here: http://rgz.ca/gaming/fenix-rage-review-rage-inducing/

tl;dr:

Fenix Rage is rage inducing, that much is clear, but it's also a game I wish we'd see more of. Games designed from the ground up to be insanely difficult with a simple core set of rules and then demand more out of the player to complete all of the goals the game puts forth. It is a game that you could spend literal hours on even the first set of levels just trying to obtain all of the cookies and all of the stars, if you were so inclined. Me, I'm just happy to have completed a single level pack in any way, shape, or form. The game was so much more difficult than I could have imagined but that's what makes it great.

reviewText:
Super Meat Boy with some interesting twists, but is it better or worse?

Well, Super Meat Boy is still the Nr.1 in it's genre and Fenix Rage isn't going to change that. Is it hard? Yes! Is it bad? Actually, no, it's surprisingly good! It has a unique dash mechanic which changes the game quite drastically, also, infinite double jumping! The controls are simple and very responsive too. It looks decent, but it isn't going to blow your mind in any way, except for maybe the last world. The music is pretty basic, nothing special, you probably should listen to your own soundtrack.

The level design is overall pretty good with some exceptions, a few of them are VERY luck-based and can get frustrating because of it. The biggest problem in my opinion are the difficulty-spikes, I had much more trouble with the first boss than with the last boss for example, maybe you get stuck in one levels and in the next you don't even die once, it's pretty weird. About those levels, there are a lot of them, each with secondary objectives like getting cookies (you can unlock real-life cookie recipes!) and more. Completing everything (+ secondary objectives) could easily take you 80+ hours (depending on your skill level).

Overall I would say it's pretty fun and satisfying to play (aside from a few luck-based level) and you should consider getting it if you loved Super Meat Boy.

My rating would be a 7/10

reviewText:
Fenix Rage has often been compared to Super Meat Boy. They're both very diffcult platformers. However, while Super Meat Boy features a single (or double if you play as certain characters) jump, in Fenix Rage, you can jump an infinite amount of times. You can also dash left or right an infinite amount of times. It's a very different experience, and I'd argue a better, albeit shorter one.

The visuals are extremely impressive; much more so than Super Meat Boy. Menus pop, animations are fluid, and the game overall looks fantastic. It was very nice to look at after playing so many games that opt to take the 16 bit graphics route, which I despise. The cutscenes look great too. Yes, there is a story, but I'm not entirely sure what it is. However, games like this are rarely about the story, so this is easily forgiven.

The game features many different things to do. The basic premise is to get from point A to point B, but there some twists to this. First, there is a cookie hidden in each level. If you find all of them in a world (20 levels, 20 cookies), you will unlock a cookie recipe. That's pretty neat. There are occasionally red boxes hidden in levels two; about 2 or 3 in a world. If you get to them in time, you'll unlock a level in a secret world, which automatically rewards you with a cookie if you complete it. There are also 3 different stars you can earn in each level. A yellow star can be earned for completing a level in a certain amount of time, a red star can be earned for completing a level by only using a certain number of dashes and jumps, and a blue star can be earned in a mode called God Mode." In God Mode
recommended: and have to touch all of the enemies on the screen (thereby killing them) in a time limit.\n\nYellow stars are decently hard to earn. I'm not really into speedrunning
hoursPlayed: so I only earned about 40 of them. However
voteText: yellow stars are also the most important. You can unlock minigames by spending yellow stars. Red stars and blue stars can't be used for anything
votesHelpful: but not a huge deal. The minigames are... decent. If you're looking for a simple diversion when you're really
commentsCount: you'll probably only play them once.\n\nRed stars are the most fun to earn
column16: in my opinion. Only being able to jump or dash a certain number of times adds a new challenge to the game. I had a good time earning all of them.\n\nI wasn't that excited about God Mode
column17: though. I think I earned about 10 blue stars before I stopped wanting to earn any more. As said before

reviewText: Fenix Rage	 is a good one - it has responsive controls, pleasant look, challenge and a neat score. But also it has one major flaw - it just CREAMS  Super Meat Boy	.\n\nAlmost a complete rip-off - from character design to music - this game just ain't got it's own distinguishable style. First set of levels - a world - is called Red Forest" (in  Super Meat Boy	 - "The Forest"); worlds have 20 levels in them in both titles; you can collect "cookies" (in  Super Meat Boy	 - "bandages"); main character is square-shaped
date: just like our good ol' buddy SMB; music is the same blend of heavy guitar riffs and rapid electronic solos; you can stick to and jump off the walls in both games...\n\nI can go on but I think it's enough on this. Though I cannot dislike  Fenix Rage	 because it is made with care and is a qualitative piece of work. Just let me remind you that in hell a special place is reserved for plagiarism. And remember this: it's not even close to how good  Super Meat Boy	 is."

reviewText: Constant, tedious struggle for right" microsecond and "certain" pixel.\n\nIt's about:curious mix of jumping
date: dashing and free-falling to beat the level.\nWhy you should play this:you like hardcore platformers
recommended: especially "death-start again" type;\nthoughtful level-design:\nlevel's structure is usually complex
hoursPlayed: sometimes includes kind of "dimensional" ("where to go?" or "how to get there?") puzzle;\nlevels are short - so
voteText: the moment between your mistake and chance to try to overcome the difficult part is very small: it helps to save desire to attempt again and again;\nincluded "challenges" - you can try to beat the par time to obtain a "Star" and unlock some arcade mini-games or collect a "Cookie" to get access to a recipe and bake it in real-life (if you want).wide setting filling: a lot of mini-games and each with it's own rules - of course the basics are simple
helpfulPercent: but still it's nice when game offers something besides the "main-part".\nWhy you may not like it:questionable balance:\nin general
votesHelpful: it's ruthless: pushed button in wrong microsecond - start again
votesTotal: touched some enemy's pixel - start again
commentsCount: you need to beat the level to get access to further one - usually that's easy and even boring because you can skip some (and sometimes the most) part of the level on your way to the extaction point;\nso
column16: there's time par for each level - to encourage you make everything fast to get a "Star": doesn't help because if you try to make everything very fast (time pars are very tight)
column17: myriads of mistakes will follow and you find yourself repeating the same "few-seconds-level" hundreds of times;\ngetting a "Cookie" brings some interest
column18: but only partly - the reason is the same: one mistake and start from scratch again;\ngame doesn't offer so-called "relax" period - the whole level is one big tension source: every part of it demands preciseness
column19: no zones to take a breathe
column22: follows immidiately. controls are firm - you can't change them
column24: if you don't have gamepad with keys similar to XBOX-controller you might face problems and deal with them by yourself.\nIt's not a bad game
column25: but it has some certain problems with the aspect which is included in every game - "Reward for trying" and "Punishment for daring": rewards here are interesting
column27: punishments are far opposite - instantly walk into.\nSo
column28:
rather sooner than later you may find that "Reward" not worth wasted time and nerves.

In a nutshell: it's just too unfriendly to a gamer to be recommended... Unless you have a lot of leisure time to practice and patience of a saint.

P.S. Dear dev(s)

reviewText: I'd recommend it, I guess if you like speed and platforming.\n\nIt's all the rage and gets all the 90s kids in the yard when they hear Precision platformer". reviewText:
Incredibly easy with infinite jumps and dashes. I guess for some it may be difficult, but to me it's just a button masher. I tried to like this game--significant time investment, stars, cookies, top 20 times on most levels--but after a certain point it falls flat.

I recommend skipping it.

Instead give Dustforce or Runner a try. Or for a similar style to this, the Jumper series. Or, if you haven't played Super Meatboy, go grab that now.

reviewText:
I finished super meat boy about a month ago (I know, I'm late...), and was feeling an emptiness inside me. Now I found this game and I feel complete again!

although the mechanics are different, these following aspects are copied from Super meat boy:
-Annoying first screen recommending controller (I'll play however I want :P)
-cutscenes skip when I press fn to change volume
-game crashes after alt shifting

I cant believe the second one wasnt made on purpose to be like SMB. if it is on purpose awesome attention to detail!

edit: Apparently you can even find timed portals on certain levels that allow you to play a retro version of the game. wonder where that idea came from...
